title: Patriots owner Robert Kraft named a semifinalist for 2026 Pro Football Hall of Fame Class
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Patriots owner Robert Kraft advanced to the semifinal round for the Pro Football Hall of Fame’s Class of 2026.
Kraft is competing in the contributor category, which was narrowed from 21 to nine semifinalists.
The Hall of Fame selection committee's semifinalist discussions will occur in a virtual meeting on November 11.

title: Several police officials in Karen Read’s case faced scrutiny or discipline. Where are they now?
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Canton Police Sergeant placed on leave for unspecified misconduct allegations linked to Karen Read case.
Former State Police Trooper Michael Proctor fired after accusations of evidence fabrication and inappropriate conduct.
Canton Detective Kevin Albert disciplined for drinking on duty during investigation; received three unpaid eight-hour shifts.

title: How Mike Vrabel, Patriots players reacted to lack of moves at trade deadline
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: The New England Patriots did not make any trades at the deadline despite a strong playoff positioning.
Coach Mike Vrabel emphasized commitment to current players, comparing trades to a state of being either pregnant or not.
Patriots lead the AFC East with a 7-2 record, focusing on long-term strategy around quarterback Drake Maye.

title: 5 best new restaurant openings and dining updates in Boston (Nov. 6, 2025)
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Aatma Curry House, opening November 2025 in Brighton, offers a unique Indian menu featuring masala-spiced burgers.
Incredible India in Waltham will feature a new bar and updated menu, opening late 2025 or early 2026.
Sea Dog Brewing Co. will open its second Massachusetts location in Lowell in February 2026, offering draft beer and bar food.

title: Lindsay Clancy wants murder trial moved to Boston amid ‘inflammatory’ media coverage
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Lindsay Clancy's lawyer seeks to move her murder trial from Plymouth County to Boston due to intense media coverage.
Clancy is accused of murdering her three children and has pleaded not guilty, citing postpartum mental illness as a defense.
Her attorney argues that prejudicial publicity has impeded her right to a fair trial in Plymouth County.

title: Rare ‘deep-diving’ whales spotted off Mass. coast
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Three rare True's beaked whales were spotted by the New England Aquarium 130 miles off Cape Cod in October.
The Anderson Cabot Center for Ocean Life survey team recorded over 700 marine animals off Cape Cod, including 402 common dolphins.
True's beaked whales are difficult to spot due to their ability to hold their breath for hours and inconspicuous surface behavior.

title: One of Mass.’s most expensive towns launches plan to combat antisemitism after 3 swastika incidents
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Weston launches anti-antisemitism plan after three swastika incidents at middle and high schools.
Weston Public Schools collaborate with the Anti-Defamation League and police on a response guide.
New curriculum guide on combating hate to be vetted over winter and introduced in spring.

title: Preserved in 1967: 93-year-old seller’s Natick home is an ode to his late wife
author: Madeline Bilis
bullets: Larry Wolozin's 1967 home in Natick, listed at $999,000, retains its mid-century design as envisioned by his late wife.
The 2,488 sq. ft. home features four bedrooms, colorful patterned wallpaper, and a built-in indoor hot tub.
Bright blue carpets and blue-themed decor are prevalent throughout the house, showcasing Norma Wolozin's favorite color.

title: USA Today readers really like JetBlue. Here’s why.
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: JetBlue ranked No. 1 for best business class cabin and in-flight food in USA Today's 2025 10Best Readers’ Choice Awards.
The airline offers complimentary snacks, free high-speed Wi-Fi, and live TV, ranking No. 2 in in-flight entertainment.
JetBlue ranked No. 3 overall, praised for new aircraft, extensive routes, and generous legroom in economy class.

title: Trevor Story discussed why he didn’t opt out of Red Sox contract
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Trevor Story chose not to opt out of his Red Sox contract, staying for the final two years and $55 million.
Story expressed his loyalty to the Red Sox, citing his love for the organization and belief in the team's potential.
In 2025, Story had a healthy season, hitting .263 with 25 home runs and 31 stolen bases despite past injuries.
